title: Ukraine Adviser to Testify John Bolton Warned U.S. Diplomats About Giuliani
text:
WASHINGTON—National security adviser John Bolton warned U.S. diplomats in June that Rudy Giuliani, President Trump’s personal attorney, could pose an obstacle to improving the White House’s relations with Ukraine, according to prepared testimony by a State Department official.

Christopher Anderson, who served as special adviser for Ukraine negotiations for two years until July 2019, is set to testify to House impeachment investigators on Wednesday that Mr. Bolton in a June 13 meeting supported “increased senior White House engagement” with Ukraine. But Mr. Bolton, who left his post last month, expressed concern that Mr. Giuliani “was a key voice with the President on Ukraine,” which could hamper efforts to strengthen the relationship, according to a copy of Mr. Anderson’s opening statement obtained by The Wall Street Journal.

Mr. Anderson, a longtime foreign service officer, attended the meeting with Kurt Volker, his boss at the time and then-U.S. special representative for Ukraine negotiations. Mr. Volker, who has resigned from his post, testified to House committees earlier this month.

Mr. Bolton’s warning—as described by Mr. Anderson—suggests the former national security adviser was aware of Mr. Giuliani’s influence over the president on Ukraine policy several weeks before a July 25 phone call in which Mr. Trump would press his Ukrainian counterpart to investigate Democrat Joe Biden and other matters, echoing calls Mr. Giuliani had made for months. Mr. Bolton, in an unusual move, didn’t listen in on the call.

Mr. Anderson is one of two State Department officials testifying on Wednesday. His successor, Catherine Croft, also will speak to House committees as part of the impeachment inquiry investigating whether Mr. Trump and Mr. Giuliani abused the power of the presidency to press a foreign country to investigate a political rival. Mr. Trump has defended his actions as appropriate and has decried the investigation as a “hoax.”

The State Department cited a White House counsel directive in an effort to block both witnesses from testifying, according to their lawyers. But both were served with a subpoena and therefore obliged to comply, their lawyers said.

Mr. Anderson is expected to tell investigators that he relayed Mr. Bolton’s message about Mr. Giuliani to George Kent, a deputy assistant secretary of state who testified this month.

Five days after that June 13 meeting in which Mr. Bolton expressed concerns about Mr. Giuliani, officials met again at the U.S. Energy Department, where Mr. Volker, Energy Secretary Rick Perry, Ambassador to the European Union Gordon Sondland and Acting Ambassador to Ukraine Bill Taylor discussed how to navigate U.S. foreign policy toward Ukraine. Among the topics, Mr. Anderson said, was “how to address Mr. Giuliani’s continued calls for a corruption investigation.” After the meeting, Mr. Anderson spoke with Mr. Taylor—who testified last week about his concerns over the calls for investigations and Mr. Giuliani’s role in Ukraine policy—and the two “agreed on the importance of not calling for any investigations” for Ukraine to undertake.

Mr. Anderson left his role working for Mr. Volker on July 12, when Ms. Croft took it over. Neither Mr. Anderson nor Ms. Croft is the whistleblower whose complaint, filed in August, helped spark the impeachment inquiry, their lawyers said.

Both officials will testify that Mr. Trump had a longstanding aversion to Ukraine. Mr. Anderson said that when Russia escalated its conflict with Ukraine by seizing Ukrainian military vessels in November 2018, State Department officials prepared a statement condemning Russia for the move. Senior White House officials subsequently blocked the statement from being released, Mr. Anderson said. Mr. Volker issued a tweet that day criticizing Russia’s actions.

The State Department issued a statement the next day condemning “this aggressive Russian action.”

Ms. Croft, a foreign service officer since 2010 who served as the National Security Council’s Ukraine director before she was asked to succeed Mr. Anderson in May 2019, said Mr. Trump repeatedly described Ukraine as corrupt while deciding whether to provide the country with Javelin missile systems in December 2017. Mr. Trump made similar comments in a September 2017 meeting with then-Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko, she said.

Ms. Croft’s testimony also reveals an intriguing new subplot related to the effort by Mr. Giuliani and others to oust the former ambassador to Ukraine, Marie Yovanovitch. Mr. Trump ultimately ordered her removed this past spring after hearing concerns from Mr. Giuliani and others that she was obstructing efforts to push for a Ukrainian investigation into Mr. Biden and his son, Hunter Biden. Ms. Yovanovitch, in testimony earlier this month, described a “concerted campaign” against her by Mr. Giuliani and others.

While she was serving on the NSC from July 2017 to July 2018, Ms. Croft said she received several calls from lobbyist Robert Livingston, who told her Ms. Yovanovitch “should be fired.” Mr. Livingston described Ms. Yovanovitch as an “Obama holdover” and linked her to George Soros, a Democratic megadonor, Ms. Croft said. Ms. Yovanovitch strenuously disputed allegations of political bias in her congressional testimony.

“It was not clear to me at the time—or now—at whose direction or at whose expense Mr. Livingston was seeking the removal of Ambassador Yovanovitch,” Ms. Croft said. She said she reported the calls to her boss, former NSC official Fiona Hill —who testified this month—and to Mr. Kent. She didn’t hear of any action taken in response.

Ms. Croft didn’t specify when Mr. Livingston contacted her. In June 2018, Justice Department records show, Mr. Livingston registered to represent a firm linked to Yulia Tymoshenko, the former Ukrainian prime minister who at the time was running for president against Volodymyr Zelensky, the current president, and Mr. Poroshenko. Over the following months, Mr. Livingston contacted dozens of government officials in an effort to arrange meetings for Ms. Tymoshenko in Washington, among them Messrs. Trump, Bolton and Volker as well as Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, according to public records.

Ms. Tymoshenko met with Messrs. Volker and Anderson in December 2018, accompanied by Mr. Livingston, the records show. The following day, another lobbyist at Mr. Livingston’s firm introduced her to Mr. Giuliani. They discussed, among other matters, “the provision of US assistance to Ukraine,” according to her website.

It couldn’t be determined if Mr. Livingston was pushing for the ambassador’s removal on Ms. Tymoshenko’s behalf. Ms. Yovanovitch during her tenure had fraught relations with some senior Ukrainian officials, who viewed her as aligned with Mr. Poroshenko. When Ms. Tymoshenko came in third in the presidential election this spring, she accused Mr. Poroshenko of cheating.

—Julie Bykowicz contributed to this article.
